ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course was not what I expected at first. I thought that the class would be primarily about a close analysis of literature, but our conversations ended up being quite literary theory based and we frequently talked about the politics and reception of the novel we were looking at, not just doing close reading. At first, I did not particularly like this, however, throughout the duration of the course I came to appreciate the importance of doing this sort of analysis. Having taken this course, I believe I have learnt how to read rapidly (we went through one novel/play per week) and also how to write engaging discussion posts which actually help guide discussion during class. Furthermore, I have had an incredible introduction to post-colonial literature which I was not expecting, but which I think has open my eyes up to a whole new way of thinking about literature. I also took this class alongside a course on the history of South Africa, and the pairing was incredibly intellectually productive!
I learnt to better read and apply postcolonial theory. I also practiced discussing postcolonial literature sensibly and cooperatively.
I learned how to read post-colonial works through academic frameworks and also how to incorporate these frameworks into my own writing.

This course teaches you, first and foremost, how to evaluate the political role of English language as both a symptom and tool of global imperialism. The texts you read in the class are interesting in and of themselves, but they all tie into a unified colonial history.

More than anything else, this course gave me new ways of reading (for agency, for local knowledge, for ideology, for women, etc), and invaluable insights on topics of relevance for postcolonial studies, such as orality, anglophonism, native languages, mental colonization, gender, and health. Essays and reading responses were interesting, well structured, and valuable, but most of my learning took place in our seminars, which were incredibly productive and thought provoking.
Ways to best use my resources and feedback to improve my writing

Studying world English literatures through a postcolonial lens, this class taught me to constantly trouble and question the power dynamics inherent in the things we read. We broke down what it means for there to be a canon, what complexities authors have towards the English language, and how English as a force and tool shapes world literature written in it. 

I learned so much about the historical and social underpinnings of the literature we read. This class transformed the way that I think critically about literaturecompletely unbarring forms of analysis.

Studying world English literatures through a postcolonial lens, this class taught me to constantly trouble and question the power dynamics inherent in the things we read. We broke down what it means for there to be a canon, what complexities authors have towards the English language, and how English as a force and tool shapes world literature written in it. I learned so much about the historical and social underpinnings of the literature we read. This class transformed the way that I think critically about literaturecompletely unbarring forms of analysis.
Reading strategies for global English texts; Knowledge of post colonial theory and how to apply it to novels
This class really developed my writing, particularly using theory and secondary essays to aid my critical analysis.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths:
We cover a huge variety of literature in style, content and location, all linked together by post-colonialism. 
The professor's comments were incredibly helpful and she was absolutely wonderful 

Weaknesses: 
Perhaps the course was a little too focused on theory which meant that students could get away with not having done the reading since we were not doing close analysis

Strengths: Steph is an incredible professor who leads discussions very well! The syllabus is also very interesting, and the student contributions were mostly very insightful. 

No weaknesses.
Steph is amazing and she does a great job at meeting everyone where they are at. I feel like her enthusiasm for the course really allowed me to learn a lot, and learn happily.

I think this course was great  well organized, interesting texts, etc.  but I think it would have been great to spend a little more time on some of the texts (the books, mainly) and a little less time on others (the articles, poems, etc.).

Strengths: fantastic seminars!!! The books were interesting in themselves but our discussions really took them to new levels. The structure for readings responses worked very well and I enjoyed both writing my own reflections and reading those of my class mates. I spent quite a lot of time on this course, but it never quite felt like work. Steph played a huge role in this, because of all the energy, curiosity, and attention to ideas that she brought into our seminars. She's amazing! Also, our guest seminar with Denise DeCaires was BRILLIANT; that woman is a genius. Lastly, the postcolonial theory we read was very valuable - I wish we would have read it even earlier during the semester. Weaknesses: none!

This course was a wonderful introduction to the idea of the Anglophone tradition outside of England and the US. Professor Newell did a great job introducing new ways of engaging with our texts through supplementary theoretical texts and shorter works like fiction and essays.

Strengths: offered me lots of helpful feedback on my work, such that it recognized my strengths and points for improvement.
Weaknesses: none in particular

ENGL 128 with Professor Steph Newell was the most intellectually exciting and rewarding class Ive taken at Yale thus far. Discussions were constantly rich and always wonderful. 

Highlights included seminar with Abdulrazak Gurnah and brilliant guest appearance by Denise DeCaires Narain.

ENGL 128 with Professor Steph Newell was the most intellectually exciting and rewarding class Ive taken at Yale thus far. Discussions were constantly rich and always wonderful. Highlights included seminar with Abdulrazak Gurnah and brilliant guest appearance by Denise DeCaires Narain.

Strengths - Steph is awesome, good reading list,
Weakness - not focused on close reading like foundational seminars are; more interested in how books are in conversations with each other / theory
Strengths  Steph is absolutely awesome. Class was engaging and very supportive. A good mix of students speaking versus Steph. She guided discussion really well.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely! The course was incredibly engaging, and having never before studied post-colonial literature I now believe it is an essential aspect of the 'canon'. Professor Newell went above and beyond to give us extra resources and to build/connect our ideas during class! This resulted in an interactive and lively seminar.
Yes! The course offers a superb introduction to postcolonial literatures and teaches students to read and understand works outside the Western canon.
Yes! Steph is great and the book selection for this course is also super diverse and interesting.
Yes, this is a great course. Take it with Steph if you can!

This course (with Steph!!) is an opportunity to read great books, have genuine and interesting discussions, receive feedback from an awesome professor, and gain whole news ways of reading/writing/thinking/talking about the world. TAKE IT!!! It's nothing short of fantastic.
Yes, this course will introduce a plethora of topics related to post colonial theory and literature that I hadnt learned enough about before

I absolutely wouldI took this class as one of my foundational requirements for the English major, and it completely transformed my engagement with literature and the English language. I would recommend it to anyone in and outside the major.

I absolutely wouldI! I took this class as one of my foundational requirements for the English major, and it completely transformed my engagement with literature and the English language. I would recommend it to anyone in and outside the major.

Really solid course, particularly with Steph. She made class engaging and fun and really helped me improve my writing. Solid syllabus, which got better towards the end in my opinion! Particularly Afterlives  it was so good and the author visited which was ABSOLUTELY SO COOL AND A HIGHLIGHT OF MY YEAR. Also, Denise co-taught a class with Steph and it was THE BEST. Shes wicked smart, perceptive, funny, awesome  an expert on Kincaid  and I would love her to become a guest professor here. Please please recruit her to come to Yale because she fills a gap in course offerings.
